case_vignette: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of persistent cough productive of white phlegm. He coughs consistently throughout the day, and he has not noticed any particular triggers that make it worse. He has also recently experienced some shortness of breath with exertion. He has not had any weight loss, fever, or chills. He had similar symptoms last year, which lasted about 6 months. He has hypertension, for which he takes amlodipine. He has worked in construction for the past 10 years. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an end-expiratory wheeze throughout all lung zones.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been coughing up white phlegm for the past four months and I'm short of breath when I do things that require effort.
How old are you?
I am 48 years old.
Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications?
I have high blood pressure and I take amlodipine.
Is there a history of lung disease in your family?
I haven't mentioned any family history of lung disease.
Do you have a history of smoking or exposure to environmental pollutants?
Yes, I've smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 30 years, and I've worked in construction for the past 10 years.
**Final Diagnosis:** Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
